User:695782484bda.name: Nader Dabit
User:695782484bda.bio: Developer Advocate at AWS Mobile — Specializing in Teaching and Building React & React Native — http://reactnative.training https://aws.amazon.com/mobile

Paragraph:44896d637a87_0.text: Writing Custom React Hooks for GraphQL

Paragraph:44896d637a87_1.name: 3ccb
Paragraph:44896d637a87_1.text: How to create custom React hooks to handle common GraphQL operations.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_3.name: 2fcf
Paragraph:44896d637a87_3.text: With the recent release of the new React APIs at React Conf 2018 there has been a flurry of discussion & open source libraries created around the new opportunities that hooks have made available to React developers.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_4.name: 877c
Paragraph:44896d637a87_4.text: When hooks first came out, I had a question:

Paragraph:44896d637a87_6.name: 6baa
Paragraph:44896d637a87_6.text: What I learned was that, at their core, hooks allow developers to do 2 things that either were not possible before without an additional library or that were much more difficult before the new API was created:

Paragraph:44896d637a87_7.name: f1ef
Paragraph:44896d637a87_7.text: Use state within a functional React component.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_8.name: c696
Paragraph:44896d637a87_8.text: Make shared behaviors across different components into a hook, that you previously could not really refactor into shared code.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_9.name: 7d1c
Paragraph:44896d637a87_9.text: Because I’ve been working a lot with GraphQL (specifically AWS AppSync), I immediately thought of using hooks to more easily set up GraphQL subscriptions:

Paragraph:44896d637a87_11.name: 71a1
Paragraph:44896d637a87_11.text: After getting subscriptions working, my mind jumped next to “what about queries & mutations?”.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_12.name: f66a
Paragraph:44896d637a87_12.text: Believe it or not, because I did not fully understand how to work with explicit asynchronous calls with React hooks, the idea of subscriptions was easier for me to immediately grok than mutations & subscriptions.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_13.name: 72db
Paragraph:44896d637a87_13.text: In this post, I’ll walk you through what I have learned & how to perform GraphQL queries, mutations, & subscriptions using custom React hooks.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_15.name: eaa8
Paragraph:44896d637a87_15.text: The three hooks we’ll be working with are:

Paragraph:44896d637a87_17.name: f544
Paragraph:44896d637a87_17.text: Docs: The function passed to useEffect will run after the render is committed to the screen. Think of effects as an escape hatch from React’s purely functional world into the imperative world.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_18.text: The way I’ve thought of useEffect is similar to the way I would have thought about componentDidMount & componentDidUpdate in the past.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_20.text: Docs: Returns a stateful value, and a function to update it.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_21.name: 01bd
Paragraph:44896d637a87_21.text: We will use useState to keep up with state in our functional components.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_23.name: 7ffb
Paragraph:44896d637a87_23.text: Docs: An alternative to useState. Accepts a reducer of type (state, action) => newState, and returns the current state paired with a dispatch method.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_24.name: b4ad
Paragraph:44896d637a87_24.text: useReducer works exactly how redux reducers work. We’ll use useReducer when we need to maintain state between multiple parts of our hook when necessary.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_25.name: b095
Paragraph:44896d637a87_25.text: If you’re looking to learn more about hooks, the two resources that helped me really understand how they work are the docs here, & Ryan Florence React Conf talk here.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_26.name: a32e
Paragraph:44896d637a87_26.text: I’ll be using the AWS Amplify GraphQL client with an AWS AppSync API in this example, but if you’d like to follow along using the Apollo client, you can use the client with a similar API by using the following configuration:

Paragraph:44896d637a87_29.name: 430e
Paragraph:44896d637a87_29.text: Update: In the future, React Suspense & React-cache will have a first-class method of handling asynchronous data fetching & will provide a possibly better API for queries. I’ve set up a working example here if you’re interested in new & unstable things 😀.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_30.name: 025e
Paragraph:44896d637a87_30.text: The first thing we’ll look at how to do is perform a GraphQL query. There are two ways to think about doing this:

Paragraph:44896d637a87_31.name: cccc
Paragraph:44896d637a87_31.text: Query immediately when the component renders

Paragraph:44896d637a87_32.name: 75b6
Paragraph:44896d637a87_32.text: Have a button or event that triggers the query

Paragraph:44896d637a87_33.name: ed43
Paragraph:44896d637a87_33.text: Let’s look at how to do both.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_34.name: b525
Paragraph:44896d637a87_34.text: Hook to query when the component renders

Paragraph:44896d637a87_36.name: fd92
Paragraph:44896d637a87_36.text: In this example we’ve created a hook to query from the GraphQL API immediately when the hook is called.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_37.name: fb89
Paragraph:44896d637a87_37.text: We use the useState hook to create some initial state, setting the todos array to an empty array.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_38.name: b7f7
Paragraph:44896d637a87_38.text: When the hook is used, useEffect will be triggered, querying the API & updating the todos array. Here, we’re using useEffect similarly to how you might have used componentDidMount in a class component.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_39.name: 513f
Paragraph:44896d637a87_39.text: Finally, the hook returns the most up to date version of the todos array.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_40.name: 990d
Paragraph:44896d637a87_40.text: Now, how would we use this hook? Well, it’s actually pretty easy:

Paragraph:44896d637a87_42.name: 6d3b
Paragraph:44896d637a87_42.text: When we call useQuery, it returns an array with the most up to date version of our todo list. In the view we then map over the todos array.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_44.name: d173
Paragraph:44896d637a87_44.text: What if we wanted to wait for an event before calling the query? Let’s take a look at how to call the query when a user clicks on a button.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_46.name: a5d5
Paragraph:44896d637a87_46.text: In this hook, we have a function called queryTodos that we will be using to call the API. The main difference here is that we are no longer using the useEffect hook to handle any side effects. When the hook loads, we don’t really do anything other than set some initial state.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_47.name: 50f5
Paragraph:44896d637a87_47.text: In the return we now are returning an array of values vs a single value. The first value is the array of todos, the second value is the function call to trigger the API operation.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_48.name: 4c0a
Paragraph:44896d637a87_48.text: Now, when we want to use the hook we can import the two values from the hook:

Paragraph:44896d637a87_51.name: cc7a
Paragraph:44896d637a87_51.text: Now that we know how to query for data, let’s look at how to create mutations.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_52.name: 4c25
Paragraph:44896d637a87_52.text: Well, there’s actually no hook needed for mutations. They can be created directly from the component:

Paragraph:44896d637a87_55.name: a8b5
Paragraph:44896d637a87_55.text: One very cool use case (& one that fits perfectly with the paradigm of hooks) is handling GraphQL subscriptions.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_56.name: 0a6e
Paragraph:44896d637a87_56.text: Because subscriptions have been typically created & torn down using lifecycle methods in a class, the new useEffect hook from React is the perfect place for subscriptions to be implemented.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_57.name: 1b1f
Paragraph:44896d637a87_57.text: For this example, we’ll first query the initial array of todos & store them in the state when they are returned in a useEffect hook when the component loads.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_58.name: 12c6
Paragraph:44896d637a87_58.text: We’ll create another useEffect hook to create a GraphQL subscription. The subscription will listen for new todos being created. When a new todo is created, the subscription will fire & we’ll update the todos array to add the new todo in the subscription data.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_59.name: 49fb
Paragraph:44896d637a87_59.text: The way that we’re managing state here is different than in the past when we used useState. Here, we’re using a reducer by leveraging the useReducer hook because we need to share state across multiple effects but only want the subscription to fire when the component loads. In order to achieve this, we’ll manage all of our state in this single reducer that will be used in both useEffect hooks.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_61.name: 49f5
Paragraph:44896d637a87_61.text: In the above subscription hook, we first fetch the initial array of todos. Once they come back from the API, we update the todos array in the state.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_62.name: 903f
Paragraph:44896d637a87_62.text: We also set up a subscription to listen for new todos, when they are created we update the todos array in the state.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_64.name: 32cb
Paragraph:44896d637a87_64.text: In the main application, we import the todos & map over them in our UI.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_65.name: 245f
Paragraph:44896d637a87_65.text: Getting subscriptions to work properly with useReducer took some time for me to figure out. Thanks to hurabielle marc for helping me figure out the solution!

Paragraph:44896d637a87_67.name: 31ae
Paragraph:44896d637a87_67.text: I have not touched on caching or optimistic UI / working with the Apollo store, though I would be really interested to see some examples of hooks that managed caching / optimistic UI.

Paragraph:44896d637a87_68.text: In our examples of working with hooks we’ve used the AWS Amplify GraphQL client that does not yet support caching, but both the Apollo Client & AWS AppSync JS SDK both do & can be used with a similar API using client.query, client.mutate, & client.subscribe (see docs here).

Paragraph:44896d637a87_70.name: 4f9a
Paragraph:44896d637a87_70.text: I am a Developer Advocate at AWS Mobile working with projects like AWS AppSync and AWS Amplify, the author of React Native in Action, & the editor of React Native Training & OpenGraphQL.
